review_title: Disorganised leadership and poor communication, but some great people
pros:
Plenty of passionate and intelligent colleagues who truly care and believe in the work they do.

There's a good protection of work/life balance.

The mission and goals of the company are great, it's just a shame that the way in which the company is run hugely detracts from this.
cons:
In my time at Sustrans I was left quite isolated and with an insufficient amount of work to do, in spite of repeated efforts to ask for more responsibilities.

Re-structuring decisions at the company left a lot of uncertainty for my, and many other, roles -consequently a lot of the people I respected most at the company left in the wake of decisions coming from senior leadership. It's worth noting that certain members of senior leadership at Sustrans Scotland leave a lot to be desired when it comes to communication, competency and compassion.

Sustrans pays really quite poorly compared to other similar companies - while in 2022 there was a promise of a pay review taking this discrepancy into account alongside the rising cost of living/inflation in the UK, the end result from this review came in woefully under what was promised. Such instances really let the company down in terms of culture and leadership.

Sustrans has a lot to learn about mental health support as well - I returned to work from a depression diagnosis to discover I was at risk of redundancy. It took a month after this bombshell to get any kind of clarity on my job security, which struck me as careless at best, and negligent at worst. I decided to move on after this debacle, as I was left feeling isolated and disregarded by the company.

review_title: Fruit baskets and digital free hours don't compensate for poor management
pros: Some lovely people, very relaxed working culture (which can be a negative too), mission, interesting projects. You'll never have to work a minute past 5 if you don't want to, that's for sure.
cons: Unfocused (if not entirely absent) line management, lack of accountability for some bewildering and ultimately decisions, constant re-structuring without seeming to have any clear idea of what the destination being aimed for is, lack of clear guidance for staff and partners. Ultimately the pros are totally eclipsed by these things and unless you can enter into some kind of magical-thinking world of "everything we do is great, even when it isn't" or are just happy to hide away safe in the knowledge there's no effective line management, it's a deeply frustrating place to be if you're motivated to be doing more than talking a good game while tinkering round the edges of some endemic issues.

job_title: Project Officer in Saint Albans, England
pros: Being a charity, Sustrans is, by and large, staffed by people who are passionate about the work they do. A such it is a very friendly, supportive and high-energy environment in which to work. If like me you find yourself running a field office with a fair degree of autonomy from base, you have to be prepared to work on your own initiative, tackling problems head-on - although this can be hard work it is also very satisfying.
cons: As a charity, Sustrans has to keep overhead costs to a minimum. As a result, support functions can sometimes seem under-developed, although this may also be due to the youth and changing focus of the organisation.

job_title: Bike IT Officer in Reading, England
pros:
Great support for CPD - I benefitted from being able to shadow whoever I wanted within the organisation, a wide variety of training, including media training from a BBC journalist.

Flexible working conditions

Exciting, buzzing place to work with some fun socials!
cons:
There were some issues with expenses - for example I was discouraged from cycling between towns, which was a bit odd for a cycling organisation!

I was also told that if I had a work bike, I couldn't claim for other expenses associated with cycling - like extra food, which is the main cost of cycling!

Pay was really quite low, which was a major reason for leaving.

job_title: Cycle Path Fundraiser Team Leader in Portsmouth, Isle of Wight, South East England, England
pros: My Regional Coordinator, Harriet Blackmore, at least, does things by the book in a laudable, transparent and trustworthy way, not in a hair-splitting nit-picky way. It's possible to feel happy working for Sustrans and enjoy the work, the pay, and the conditions which are more than fair. Harriet is upbeat and encouraging, a great championer, making me and all the team valued. I'm able to pass those good feelings on to potential customers/customers/the public generally.
cons: The nature of the work is that it's seasonal and weather-dependent which makes it unreliable and temporary.
